author: daniellehrner
content:
IMO one of the main problem with RIPs is that most (all?) tooling providers will only add support for EIPs that are on mainnet. Taking EOF as example, the Solidity team stated that it will only merge their EOF branch into main if it's added to mainnet.

Not sure how support for 7272 will be added, if it's  done via a forked version of Solidity or simply by using assembly code. If a Solidity fork is used the EOF branch could be added as well. But that's a DX nightmare, because one would need different Solidity versions for mainnet and L2s.

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> ok I see, so the problem is basically that the RIP process has still not come close to achieving its goal of legitimizing EVM-on-L2s to easily diverge from EVM on L1

author: daniellehrner
content: The wallet providers said the same for 3047 / 7702. If it's not on mainnet they will not allocate resources to work on it. Not sure how to overcome that. Right now it looks we have to wait until most activity is on L2s and mainnet becomes less important for user interactions, but this could take years...

author: bridge-bot
content:
<adietrichs> my take: For now, RIPs are fundamentally blocked by missing L2 client support (as in, most L2s use geth, and geth has made it very clear that it will continue to exclusively target and support L1). We are exploring ways to unblock this, and will present them soon.

In the meantime, the only RIPs that can realistically be shipped are ones that have minimal implementation overhead, like 7212. But those are not enough to establish RIPs as a category to pay attention to, or some sort of "common core" L2 EVM (as in, L1 EVM extended by some common core set of RIPs) as worth targeting separately for tooling.

I am not overly worried that tooling support would remain an issue once we start to enable more RIP shipping velocity. L2s by now have a substantial enough share of the overall Ethereum userbase to warrant such support.

<eliastzr> Another hardship we‚Äôve experienced is the lack of easy integration with the global test suite:

- simple example, adding RIP-7212 broke some EF executions test (which had EOAs or SCs at 0x100), we had to make a few changes on the ef tests repo 
- another example, gas pricing has ramifications in many tests (since gas opcodes are used in some tests as addition or compute inputs) 

since ef tests runs in CI, adding a RIP that adds precompile or gas difference requires a modification in official test vectors;

author: bridge-bot
content: <tyneslol> Reth ExEx gives an API for building a full node where you can decorate it with new functionality. You import reth as a library and then can hook directly into things like the rpc to add new endpoints or the evm to add new precompiles/opcodes. The idea is to remove the need to maintain a fork of a client and instead maintain an ExEx (re @thegaram33: I'm curious how Reth ExEx makes this easier. is it just that it provides a convenient framework for modifying/extending OP Stack?)

author: bridge-bot
